item.title: Pseudolikelihood
item.description: Bayesian inference Modelling sequences We would like to model a distribution of some sequences of lenght $L$ where every element in the sequence can take $K$ different values. Write the parametric probability distribution for the sequence as a joint probability of elements in the sequence, i.e. \begin{align} p(\mathbf{x};\boldsymbol{\theta})=p(x_1, x_2,…, x_L;\boldsymbol{\theta}), \end{align} where $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ are parameters of the distribution. Now suppose that we got $N$ examples drawn from this distribution. Denote the data as $\mathbf{X}\in \mathbb{R}^{N\times L\times K}$.
